Spectroscopy and decays of the fully-heavy tetraquarks

M. Naeem Anwar naeem@itp.ac.cn CAS Key Laboratory of Theoretical Physics, Institute of Theoretical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China Helmholtz-Institut für Strahlen- und Kernphysik and Bethe Center for Theoretical Physics,

Abstract

We discuss the possible existence of the fully-heavy tetraquarks. We calculate the ground-state energy of the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} bound state, where b𝑏b stands for the bottom quark, in a nonrelativistic effective field theory framework with one-gluon-exchange (OGE) color Coulomb interaction, and in a relativized diquark model characterized by OGE plus a confining potential. Our analysis advocates the existence of uni-flavor heavy four-quark bound states. The ground state b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} tetraquark mass is predicted to be (18.72±0.02)plus-or-minus18.720.02(18.72\pm 0.02) GeV. Mass inequality relations among the lowest Q​Q​Q¯​Q¯𝑄𝑄¯𝑄¯𝑄QQ\bar{Q}\bar{Q} state, where Q∈{c,b}𝑄𝑐𝑏Q\in\{c,b\}, and the corresponding heavy quarkonia are presented, which give the upper limit on the mass of ground state Q​Q​Q¯​Q¯𝑄𝑄¯𝑄¯𝑄QQ\bar{Q}\bar{Q}. The possible decays of the lowest b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} are highlighted, which might provide useful references in the search for them in ongoing LHC experiments, and its width is estimated to be a few tens of MeV.

I Introduction

Heavy quarkonium spectroscopy is the arena of quark potential models, in which the full interaction incorporates the short-range one-gluon-exchange (OGE) and long-range confining potential Eichten:1978tg ; Richardson:1978bt ; Buchmuller:1980su ; Godfrey:1985xj ; Barnes:2005pb . To put heavy quarkonium spectroscopy in a model-independent framework, efforts have been made to develop a nonrelativistic effective field theory formalism Pineda:1997bj ; Brambilla:1999xf ; Brambilla:2004jw .

Higher-order perturbative calculations show that the lowest-lying heavy quarkonia can be assigned as weakly coupled states Pineda:1997hz ; Brambilla:1999xj ; Kniehl:2002br . They are characterized by a momentum scale m​v≫ΛQCDmuch-greater-than𝑚𝑣subscriptΛQCDmv\gg\Lambda_{\rm QCD}, where m𝑚m and v𝑣v are the heavy quark mass and velocity, respectively, and ΛQCDsubscriptΛQCD\Lambda_{\rm QCD} is the nonperturbative scale of quantum chromodynamics (QCD), and their dynamics is mainly dominated by the short-distance interaction. In particular, there is some evidence that the first few bottomonia and Bcsubscript𝐵𝑐B_{c} mesons can be identified as weakly coupled systems Titard:1993nn ; Brambilla:2000db ; Brambilla:2001fw , while the J/ψ𝐽𝜓J/\psi lies on the borderline of this classification Brambilla:2004jw . The lowest-lying doubly- and triply-heavy baryons have also been studied as weakly coupled bound states Brambilla:2005yk ; Jia:2006gw but, due to the lack of experimental incentive,111Very recently, the LHCb Collaboration announced the first measurement of the S𝑆S-wave doubly-charm baryon, the Ξc​c++superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑐𝑐absent\Xi_{cc}^{++} Aaij:2017ueg , with a mass of about 3620 MeV. this area is not as well explored as that of heavy quarkonia.

It is also worth mentioning some recent indications of the existence of mesons whose properties and quantum numbers do not fit into a traditional quarkonium interpretation (for recent reviews, see Nakamura:2010zzi ; Brambilla:2014jmp ; Chen:2016qju ; Lebed:2016hpi ; Esposito:2016noz ; Guo:2017jvc ; Ali:2017jda ; Olsen:2017bmm ). These states, including Zb​(10610)subscript𝑍𝑏10610Z_{b}(10610) and Zb​(10650)subscript𝑍𝑏10650Z_{b}(10650) Bondar , Zc​(3900)subscript𝑍𝑐3900Z_{c}(3900) Ablikim ; Liu , and Zc​(4025)subscript𝑍𝑐4025Z_{c}(4025) Ablikim2 , have similar features and must be made up of four valence quarks, as they are isovector states in the heavy quarkonium mass region. Another interesting example is X​(3872)𝑋3872X(3872) Choi:2003ue which, because of its unusual properties, does not fit well into a pure charmonium picture Godfrey:1985xj ; Eichten:1978tg ; Barnes:2005pb . Several alternative interpretations have been proposed Hanhart:2007yq ; Baru:2011rs ; Swanson:2003tb ; Pennington:2007xr ; Li:2009ad ; Danilkin:2010cc ; charmonium ; Maiani:2004vq .

Fully-heavy tetraquarks, such as b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} and the charm analog c​c​c¯​c¯𝑐𝑐¯𝑐¯𝑐cc\bar{c}\bar{c}, are of considerable interest, since they are free of light degrees of freedom and might be used as an elegant probe to investigate the interplay between both aspects of QCD: perturbative and nonperturbative. Owing to the lack of experimental incentive, only a few theoretical studies have been conducted in this field, and whether Nature allows the bound states of fully-heavy tetraquarks or not is still an open question. If it does, what are their masses and decay properties? Recently, this debate has given rise to several studies within different approaches, including the constituent quark and diquark model Bai:2016int ; Eichten:2017ual ; Karliner:2016zzc ; Berezhnoy:2011xn , chiral quark model Wu:2016vtq , chromo-electric potential model Richard:2017vry , and QCD sum rules Chen:2016jxd ; Wang:2017jtz . All of these predict the existence of fully-heavy (bottom) tetraquarks, except for Ref. Richard:2017vry , in which the authors argue that the stability of a fully-heavy system of quarks should rely on more subtle effects that are not included in the simple picture of constituent quarks. The fully-heavy tetraquark case is similar to that of polyelectrons Ps2subscriptPs2\textrm{Ps}_{2}, the bound state of two electrons and two positrons (e−​e−​e+​e+superscript𝑒superscript𝑒superscript𝑒superscript𝑒e^{-}e^{-}e^{+}e^{+}), discussed long ago by Wheeler Wheeler:1946zz . Just after the prediction of Ps2subscriptPs2\textrm{Ps}_{2}, a debate on their stability started Ore:1946zz ; Hylleraas:1947zza , but it took half a century to get experimental evidence of them Nature:2007 .

In this paper, we compute the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy. The calculations are performed within the formalism of a nonrelativistic effective field theory (NREFT) at the leading order (LO), which neglects all spin-dependent and confining interactions, and in a relativized diquark-antidiquark model, both of which are characterized by the OGE potential. We also make a rough estimate of the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} total width, in order to guide experimental searches.

The paper is organized as follows. In section II, we describe the NREFT approach to solve the system considered. At the end of this section, we include our diquark model results. Section III is devoted to discussing the results, and we compare our predictions of the mass of the Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} ground-state with those of previous studies. In Section IV, we derive a set of mass inequalities, and provide the upper limits of the ground state masses of several fully-heavy tetraquarks. In Sec. V, we highlight some possible decay modes of the Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} and give the ballpark estimate of its total decay width. Finally, we provide a short summary.

II Formalism

In this section, we describe an NREFT approach to the fully-heavy tetraquark spectroscopy, characterized by the OGE interaction. This is used to estimate the mass of the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground state. As all of the four quarks are very heavy, the tetraquark system is weakly coupled with a small size of the order 1/(mQ​αs)∼1/(mQ​v)similar-to1subscript𝑚𝑄subscript𝛼𝑠1subscript𝑚𝑄𝑣1/(m_{Q}\alpha_{s})\sim 1/(m_{Q}v), where v≪1much-less-than𝑣1v\ll 1 is the heavy quark velocity. In this case, the dynamics of the system is dominated by the OGE which provides a color Coulomb potential at the LO, and the long-distance confining potential and spin-dependent interactions become perturbations.

In addition, we also give a tetraquark (diquark-antidiquark) model prediction for the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state mass.

II.1 Nonrelativistic Hamiltonian

The nonrelativistic Hamiltonian describing the 2​Q−2​Q¯2𝑄2¯𝑄2Q-2\bar{Q} system takes the following form at the LO

ℋNR=∑i=14Ti+∑i<jVSI​(ri​j)​ ,superscriptℋNRsuperscriptsubscript𝑖14subscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝑉SIsubscriptr𝑖𝑗 \mathcal{H}^{\rm NR}=\sum_{i=1}^{4}T_{i}+\sum_{i<j}V_{\textrm{SI}}(\textbf{r}_{ij})\mbox{ }, (1)

where Ti=mi+pi2/(2​mi)subscript𝑇𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscriptp𝑖22subscript𝑚𝑖T_{i}=m_{i}+{\textbf{p}_{i}^{2}}/{(2m_{i})}, ri​j≡|ri−rj|subscriptr𝑖𝑗subscriptr𝑖subscriptr𝑗\textbf{r}_{ij}\equiv|\textbf{r}_{i}-\textbf{r}_{j}|, and the second term is the spin-independent OGE color Coulomb potential,

VSI​(ri​j)=∑i<j𝝀i2⋅𝝀j2​αs|ri−rj|​ ,subscript𝑉SIsubscriptr𝑖𝑗subscript𝑖𝑗⋅subscript𝝀𝑖2subscript𝝀𝑗2subscript𝛼𝑠subscriptr𝑖subscriptr𝑗 V_{\textrm{SI}}(\textbf{r}_{ij})=\sum_{i<j}\frac{\bm{\lambda}_{i}}{2}\cdot\frac{\bm{\lambda}_{j}}{2}\frac{\alpha_{s}}{|\textbf{r}_{i}-\textbf{r}_{j}|}\mbox{ }, (2)

where 𝝀isubscript𝝀𝑖\bm{\lambda}_{i} and 𝝀jsubscript𝝀𝑗\bm{\lambda}_{j} are color matrices and αssubscript𝛼𝑠\alpha_{s} is the strong coupling strength. The quark mass mbsubscript𝑚𝑏m_{b} is to be determined from the ground state bottomonium masses, and αssubscript𝛼𝑠\alpha_{s} is taken at the scale of the typical momentum transfer. At order αs2superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑠2\alpha_{s}^{2}, we can write mbsubscript𝑚𝑏m_{b} as Jia:2006gw

mb=Mb​b¯​(1​S)2​(1+29​αs2​(μ)).subscript𝑚𝑏subscript𝑀𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆2129superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑠2𝜇m_{b}=\frac{M_{b\bar{b}(1S)}}{2}\left(1+\frac{2}{9}\alpha_{s}^{2}(\mu)\right). (3)

Here, we take the spin-averaged mass Mb​b¯​(1​S)=(Mηb+3​MΥ)/4subscript𝑀𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆subscript𝑀subscript𝜂𝑏3subscript𝑀Υ4M_{b\bar{b}(1S)}=\left(M_{\eta_{b}}+3M_{\Upsilon}\right)/4.

II.2 Solving the four-body problem

The four-body problem is notoriously delicate. One should be careful about the choice of the wave functions, because a crude adoption may give rise to misleading conclusions, as first illustrated by Ore in 1946 in Ref. Ore:1946zz in the case of polyelectrons (e−​e−​e+​e+superscript𝑒superscript𝑒superscript𝑒superscript𝑒e^{-}e^{-}e^{+}e^{+} bound states). One year later the author, in collaboration with Hylleraas Hylleraas:1947zza , came up with an elegant prescription to handle four-body systems. This is what we are willing to use to calculate the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy, provided that we make the substitution e−→b→superscript𝑒𝑏e^{-}\rightarrow b, e+→b¯→superscript𝑒¯𝑏e^{+}\rightarrow\bar{b}.

Since the ground state is non-degenerate and its symmetries are governed by those of the Hamiltonian ℋNRsuperscriptℋNR\mathcal{H}^{\rm NR}, the spatial wave function should be symmetric under the exchange of Q1​Q2↔Q¯3​Q¯4↔subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2subscript¯𝑄3subscript¯𝑄4Q_{1}Q_{2}\leftrightarrow\bar{Q}_{3}\bar{Q}_{4}. This leads to ψspatial​(Q1​Q2)=ψspatial​(Q¯3​Q¯4)subscript𝜓spatialsubscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2subscript𝜓spatialsubscript¯𝑄3subscript¯𝑄4\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(Q_{1}Q_{2})=\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(\bar{Q}_{3}\bar{Q}_{4}). This symmetry Hylleraas:1947zza helps to reduce the number of integration variables and simplify the four-body problem. To describe the quark relative motion, we define the following Jacobi coordinates,

𝝈=𝐫1−𝐫2,𝝆=𝐫3−𝐫4,𝝀=12​(𝐫1+𝐫2−𝐫3−𝐫4),formulae-sequence𝝈subscript𝐫1subscript𝐫2formulae-sequence𝝆subscript𝐫3subscript𝐫4𝝀12subscript𝐫1subscript𝐫2subscript𝐫3subscript𝐫4{\bm{\sigma}}={\bf r}_{1}-{\bf r}_{2}~{},~{}~{}{\bm{\rho}}={\bf r}_{3}-{\bf r}_{4}~{},~{}~{}{\bm{\lambda}}=\frac{1}{2}({\bf r}_{1}+{\bf r}_{2}-{\bf r}_{3}-{\bf r}_{4})~{}, (4)

which are shown in Fig. 1.

The “physical” tetraquark color wave function can be written as a superposition of different color configurations,222In the following, we use the notation |𝐂𝟏𝟐​𝐂𝟑𝟒;𝐂𝟏𝟐𝟑𝟒⟩ketsubscript𝐂12subscript𝐂34subscript𝐂1234\left|\bf{C}_{12}\bf{C}_{34};\bf{C}_{1234}\right\rangle, where the color configuration of the quark (antiquark) pairs 12 and 34, 𝐂𝟏𝟐subscript𝐂12\bf{C}_{12} and 𝐂𝟑𝟒subscript𝐂34\bf{C}_{34}, are coupled to that of the tetraquark, 𝐂𝟏𝟐𝟑𝟒subscript𝐂1234\bf{C}_{1234}.

|ψc⟩=α​|3¯12​334;11234⟩+β​|612​6¯34;11234⟩​ ,ketsubscript𝜓c𝛼ketsubscript¯312subscript334subscript11234𝛽ketsubscript612subscript¯634subscript11234 \left|\psi_{\rm c}\right\rangle=\alpha\left|\bar{\textbf{3}}_{12}\textbf{3}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle+\beta\left|\textbf{6}_{12}\bar{\textbf{6}}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle\mbox{ }, (5)

where the coefficients α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta can be obtained by diagonalizing the model Hamiltonian on the tetraquark wave function. When the two identical heavy quarks are in the 3¯¯3\bar{\textbf{3}} color representation and in an S𝑆S-wave, the spin must be equal to 111 so as to satisfy the Pauli principle. For the two heavy quarks being in the 6 color representation and in an S𝑆S-wave, the spin needs to be 0. Therefore, the mixing between 3¯¯3\bar{\textbf{3}} and 6 color representations requires a flip of heavy quark spin, and thus is of higher order in NREFT (suppressed by v2∼0.1similar-tosuperscript𝑣20.1v^{2}\sim 0.1). Since the OGE gives an attractive interaction for 3¯¯3\bar{\textbf{3}} and a repulsive interaction for 6, at LO the ground-state color configuration should be |3¯12​334;11234⟩ketsubscript¯312subscript334subscript11234\left|\bar{\textbf{3}}_{12}\textbf{3}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle. Such a ground-state configuration has been suggested Jaffe:2004ph ; Santopinto:2006my , and more recently in Refs. Eichten:2017ual ; Wu:2016vtq ; Park:2013fda . It is also supported by recent lattice QCD studies on fully-heavy four quark systems Cardoso:2012uka .

On the basis of the |3¯12​334;11234⟩ketsubscript¯312subscript334subscript11234\left|\bar{\textbf{3}}_{12}\textbf{3}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle color configuration, the kinetic energy matrix elements can be written as

T=p𝝈22​m1+p𝝆22​m2+p𝝀22​m3=1mb​(p𝝈2+p𝝆2+2​p𝝀2),𝑇superscriptsubscriptp𝝈22subscript𝑚1superscriptsubscriptp𝝆22subscript𝑚2superscriptsubscriptp𝝀22subscript𝑚31subscript𝑚𝑏superscriptsubscriptp𝝈2superscriptsubscriptp𝝆22superscriptsubscriptp𝝀2T=\frac{\textbf{p}_{\bm{\sigma}}^{2}}{2m_{1}}+\frac{\textbf{p}_{\bm{\rho}}^{2}}{2m_{2}}+\frac{\textbf{p}_{\bm{\lambda}}^{2}}{2m_{3}}=\frac{1}{m_{b}}\bigg{(}\textbf{p}_{\bm{\sigma}}^{2}+\textbf{p}_{\bm{\rho}}^{2}+2\textbf{p}_{\bm{\lambda}}^{2}\bigg{)}, (6)

where m1subscript𝑚1m_{1}, m2subscript𝑚2m_{2} and m3subscript𝑚3m_{3} are the reduced masses of Q1​Q2subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2Q_{1}Q_{2}, Q¯3​Q¯4subscript¯𝑄3subscript¯𝑄4\bar{Q}_{3}\bar{Q}_{4} and Q1​Q2−Q¯3​Q¯4subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2subscript¯𝑄3subscript¯𝑄4Q_{1}Q_{2}-\bar{Q}_{3}\bar{Q}_{4}, respectively. where (𝝃1,𝝃2,𝝃3)≡(𝝈,𝝆,𝝀)subscript𝝃1subscript𝝃2subscript𝝃3𝝈𝝆𝝀(\bm{\xi}_{1},\bm{\xi}_{2},\bm{\xi}_{3})\equiv(\bm{\sigma},\bm{\rho},\bm{\lambda}), βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} are the oscillatory (variational) parameters, and

is the overall normalization constant. It has been recently shown that the above Gaussian variational basis is a powerful tool to obtain the ground state energy of heavy tetraquarks Park:2013fda .

It is worth noting that the color configurations |113​124;11234⟩ketsubscript113subscript124subscript11234\left|\textbf{1}_{13}\textbf{1}_{24};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle and |813​824;11234⟩ketsubscript813subscript824subscript11234\left|\textbf{8}_{13}\textbf{8}_{24};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle are linear superpositions of the two color representations of Eq. (5). In other words, one can alternatively use the bases {|3¯12​334;11234⟩;|612​6¯34;11234⟩}ketsubscript¯312subscript334subscript11234ketsubscript612subscript¯634subscript11234\left\{\left|\bar{\textbf{3}}_{12}\textbf{3}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle;\left|\textbf{6}_{12}\bar{\textbf{6}}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle\right\} or {|113​124;11234⟩;|813​824;11234⟩}ketsubscript113subscript124subscript11234ketsubscript813subscript824subscript11234\left\{\left|\textbf{1}_{13}\textbf{1}_{24};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle;\left|\textbf{8}_{13}\textbf{8}_{24};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle\right\}. For the detailed arguments, we refer to Ref. Weinstein:1983gd . A physical transition between the |3¯12​334;11234⟩ketsubscript¯312subscript334subscript11234\left|\bar{\textbf{3}}_{12}\textbf{3}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle tetraquark state and the |113​124;11234⟩ketsubscript113subscript124subscript11234\left|\textbf{1}_{13}\textbf{1}_{24};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle two-meson state333Similarly to the tetraquark model case, for simplicity in the meson-meson molecular model the color configuration is restricted to |113​124;11234⟩ketsubscript113subscript124subscript11234\left|\textbf{1}_{13}\textbf{1}_{24};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle. can occur, which is the well-known “flip-flop” transition Okiharu:2004ve . This is an important ingredient while studying the decays into two mesons if the mass of the initial tetraquark is higher than the two-meson threshold.

II.3 b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state

The eigenvalue problem is solved by means of a numerical variational approach with Gaussian trial wave functions Hwang:1995uy ; Naeem12 . The quark mass mbsubscript𝑚𝑏m_{b} is extracted via Eq. (3), where one also has to include the spin-averaged mass of the 1​S1𝑆1S (ground-state) bottomonia,

Mb​b¯​(1​S)=14​[3​MΥ​(1​S)+Mηb​(1​S)]=9.45​GeV .subscript𝑀𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆14delimited-[]3subscript𝑀Υ1𝑆subscript𝑀subscript𝜂𝑏1𝑆9.45GeV M_{b\bar{b}}(1S)=\frac{1}{4}\left[3M_{\Upsilon(1S)}+M_{\eta_{b}(1S)}\right]=9.45~{}\textrm{GeV}\mbox{ }. (9)

The other parameter, i.e., the running coupling constant αs​(μ)subscript𝛼𝑠𝜇\alpha_{s}(\mu), is taken at the scale of the typical momentum transfer in the ground-state bottomonium (μ=1.5𝜇1.5\mu=1.5 GeV). The extracted values are

mb=4.82​GeV,αs​(1.5​GeV)=0.31.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑚𝑏4.82GeVsubscript𝛼s1.5GeV0.31m_{b}=4.82~{}\text{GeV}~{},~{}~{}~{}\alpha_{\rm s}(1.5~{}{\rm GeV})=0.31\,. (10)

The spin-averaged binding energy of the 1​S1𝑆1S bottomonium is

Eb​b¯​(1​S)≡2​mb−Mb​b¯​(1​S)=(0.20±0.01)​GeV.subscript𝐸𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆2subscript𝑚𝑏subscript𝑀𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆plus-or-minus0.200.01GeVE_{b\bar{b}}(1S)\equiv 2m_{b}-M_{b\bar{b}(1S)}=(0.20\pm 0.01)~{}\textrm{GeV}. (11)

We can estimate the energy of the Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} ground-state by means of the variational method with Gaussian trial wave functions previously used in the bottomonium case and the model parameter values of Eq. (10). We get

Mb​b​b¯​b¯gs,NR=(18.72±0.02)​ GeV,superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏gsNRplus-or-minus18.720.02 GeVM_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}^{\rm gs,NR}=(18.72\pm 0.02)\mbox{ GeV}, (12)

where the uncertainty is given by the product of the binding energy and αs​(1.5​GeV)subscript𝛼s1.5GeV\alpha_{\rm s}(1.5~{}{\rm GeV}). The binding energy of the lowest four b𝑏b-quark bound state is obtained as

Eb​b​b¯​b¯​(1​S)≡4​mb−Mb​b​b¯​b¯gs,NR=(0.56±0.02)​GeV.subscript𝐸𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆4subscript𝑚𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏gsNRplus-or-minus0.560.02GeVE_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}(1S)\equiv 4m_{b}-M_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}^{\rm gs,NR}=(0.56\pm 0.02)~{}\textrm{GeV}. (13)

The extracted optimal values of the variational parameters βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i} are β1=β2=0.77subscript𝛽1subscript𝛽20.77\beta_{1}=\beta_{2}=0.77 GeV and β3=0.60subscript𝛽30.60\beta_{3}=0.60 GeV, where β1=β2subscript𝛽1subscript𝛽2\beta_{1}=\beta_{2} is due to the symmetry of the spatial wave function Hylleraas:1947zza , as discussed in the last subsection.

II.4 b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground state in a relativized diquark model

In this subsection, we provide an estimate of the fully-bottom tetraquark ground-state energy by treating the Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} configuration as a diquark, b​b𝑏𝑏bb, and antidiquark, b¯​b¯¯𝑏¯𝑏\bar{b}\bar{b}, bound state in a relativized diquark model. In this model, the diquark is an effective degree of freedom which describes two strongly correlated quarks with no internal spatial excitations. The lowest-energy diquark configurations, scalar and axial-vector, are both color anti-triplets but have different spin and flavor quantum numbers. The former, i.e., the scalar diquark, has spin-0 and its flavor wave function is antisymmetric. The latter has spin-1 and is flavor-symmetric. As mentioned in the last section, because of the Pauli principle, a (point-like) diquark made up of quarks of the same flavor can only be of the axial-vector type Debastiani:2017msn ; Jaffe:2004ph .

To calculate the energy of the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground state in diquark anti-diquark configuration, we need an evaluation of the b​b𝑏𝑏bb axial-vector diquark mass, Mav,b​bsubscript𝑀av𝑏𝑏M_{{\rm av},bb}. The diquark (antidiquark) mass is estimated by binding a b​b𝑏𝑏bb (b¯​b¯¯𝑏¯𝑏\bar{b}\bar{b}) pair via the OGE plus a confining potential Godfrey:1985xj , and we have444Notice that the parameters in this diquark model are different from those in the NREFT approach.

Mav,b​b=9.85​GeV.subscript𝑀av𝑏𝑏9.85GeVM_{{\rm av},bb}=9.85~{}{\rm GeV}. (14)

After doing that, we can compute the 1​S1𝑆1S, 0++superscript0absent0^{++} tetraquark ground-state energy in the relativized diquark model. The model Hamiltonian is characterized by the OGE plus confining potential. For more details on the model and the values of the model parameters, we refer to Ref. Anwar:2018sol . With the use of the previous value of Mav,b​bsubscript𝑀av𝑏𝑏M_{{\rm av},bb}, we get

Mb​b​b¯​b¯gs,REL=18.75​ GeV,superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏gsREL18.75 GeVM_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}^{\rm gs,REL}=18.75\mbox{ GeV}\,, (15)

which is consistent with the result obtained in the previous subsection. See also Table 1, where our relativized diquark model prediction is compared to those of previous studies. The theoretical uncertainty in the above prediction can be estimated by using the typical error of the quark model calculations. The intrinsic error in the quark model predictions is of the order of 30∼50similar-to305030\sim 50 MeV charmonium ; therefore, this diquark model prediction has the cumulative uncertainty of 𝒪​(50​MeV)𝒪50MeV\mathcal{O}(50~{}\textrm{MeV}).

III Results and Discussion

In Table 1, our NREFT and relativized diquark model results for the mass of the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state are compared with those of previous studies. The results are strongly model-dependent and vary in the range of (18.7±0.2)plus-or-minus18.70.2(18.7\pm 0.2) GeV, approximately. The differences among the results mainly stem from different choices of effective Hamiltonians, the model-parameter fitting procedures, and the use of distinct approximations in the tetraquark wave function. This last is related to the possible ways of combining the quark color representations to obtain a color singlet wave function for the tetraquark. In the last column of the table, we also report the differences between the predicted masses and the ηb​ηbsubscript𝜂𝑏subscript𝜂𝑏\eta_{b}\eta_{b} threshold, (18798±4)plus-or-minus187984(18798\pm 4) MeV Nakamura:2010zzi whose central value is used.

It is worthwhile to remind some previous studies. For example, Karliner et al. Karliner:2016zzc made a phenomenological estimation of the Q​Q​Q¯​Q¯𝑄𝑄¯𝑄¯𝑄QQ\bar{Q}\bar{Q} ground-state energies, with Q=b𝑄𝑏Q=b and c𝑐c. The authors utilized a relation between meson and baryon masses to extrapolate the binding energy of Q​Q​Q¯​Q¯𝑄𝑄¯𝑄¯𝑄QQ\bar{Q}\bar{Q} systems in the diquark model. They made the ballpark estimates of Bb​b¯​(1​S)subscript𝐵𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆B_{b\bar{b}}(1S) and the binding energy of the tetraquark with respect to the two-b​b𝑏𝑏bb-diquark threshold, and obtained a value of about 1/2121/2 for the ratio Bb​b¯​(1​S)/Bb​b​b¯​b¯​(1​S)subscript𝐵𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆subscript𝐵𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆{B_{b\bar{b}}(1S)}/{B_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}(1S)}.

Bai et al. calculated the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy by means of a phenomenological potential, whose parameters were fitted to the b​b¯𝑏¯𝑏b\bar{b} spectrum and verified by lattice simulation Bai:2016int . The b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy was obtained by solving the Schrödinger equation numerically; spin-dependent corrections and a linear confining potential were included. Their result agrees with our LO NREFT result very well, indicating that neglecting the spin-dependent and confining parts provides a very good approximation to the system under study.

A diquark model prediction of the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} and c​c​c¯​c¯𝑐𝑐¯𝑐¯𝑐cc\bar{c}\bar{c} ground-state energies was given in Ref. Berezhnoy:2011xn . There, the authors assumed tetraquarks to be made up of two almost point-like diquarks in the color-triplet configuration. The model parameters were fitted by solving a non-relativistic Schrödinger equation for the charmonium and bottomonium spectrum. The b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state mass agrees with our diquark model well.

In Ref. Ader:1981db , the authors computed the c​c​c¯​c¯𝑐𝑐¯𝑐¯𝑐cc\bar{c}\bar{c} ground-state energy within a nonrelativistic potential model. The authors concluded that the possibility of obtaining bound states depends on the assumptions made on the quark dynamics and the flavor configurations. There are also early predictions for the mass Iwasaki:1975pv and width chao:1981 of the fully-charm tetraquark, and the ground-state energies of Q2​Q¯2superscript𝑄2superscript¯𝑄2Q^{2}\bar{Q}^{2} systems, with Q∈{s,c,b,t}𝑄𝑠𝑐𝑏𝑡Q\in\{s,c,b,t\} heller:1985 . For the full mass spectrum of all-charm tetraquarks, we refer to Ref. Debastiani:2017msn . All-charm four-quark bound state has also been studied in the Bethe–Salpeter approach and the ground state was reported to be deeply bound (650 MeV) below the 2​ηc2subscript𝜂𝑐2\eta_{c} threshold Heupel:2012ua .

A study of the importance of mixing effects between tetraquark and molecular-type components is also worthwhile to be carried out, especially for those states which are close to meson-meson thresholds. The probability of a fully-heavy tetraquark to be a (Q​Q¯)−(Q​Q¯)𝑄¯𝑄𝑄¯𝑄(Q\bar{Q})-(Q\bar{Q}) hadronic molecule might be calculable without any ambiguity. It is worthwhile to mention that the possibility of an ηbsubscript𝜂b\eta_{\rm b}-ηbsubscript𝜂b\eta_{\rm b} bound state has been studied by computing the QCD van der Vaals force in the framework of potential nonrelativistic QCD in Ref. Brambilla:2016 . Given that the recent lattice nonrelativistic QCD calculation did not find any state below the noninteracting ηb​ηbsubscript𝜂𝑏subscript𝜂𝑏\eta_{b}\eta_{b} threshold Hughes:2017xie , such a study seems necessary to understand what happens.

It would also be very interesting to test the possibility of a b​b​c¯​c¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑐¯𝑐bb\bar{c}\bar{c} tetraquark that remains stable against strong decays,555All the other possible fully-heavy tetraquarks can decay strongly by annihilating at least a pair of quarks and antiquarks of the same flavor. but unfortunately there is no experimental evidence yet. The stability of heavy-light tetraquark systems is still an open question. The Q​Q​q¯​q¯𝑄𝑄¯𝑞¯𝑞QQ\bar{q}\bar{q} was shown to be stable against strong decays by Lipkin long ago666Before Lipkin, the authors of Ref. Ader:1981db also argued that XQ​Q​q¯​q¯subscript𝑋𝑄𝑄¯𝑞¯𝑞X_{QQ\bar{q}\bar{q}} is stable if the quark mass ratio mQ/mqsubscript𝑚𝑄subscript𝑚𝑞m_{Q}/m_{q} is large enough. For reasonable values of the quark mass ratio, 5∼20similar-to5205\sim 20, they predict a XQ​Q​q¯​q¯subscript𝑋𝑄𝑄¯𝑞¯𝑞X_{QQ\bar{q}\bar{q}} above but not very far from the corresponding threshold. Note that the ratios mb/mu≈16subscript𝑚𝑏subscript𝑚𝑢16m_{b}/m_{u}\approx 16, mc/mu≈5subscript𝑚𝑐subscript𝑚𝑢5m_{c}/m_{u}\approx 5, and mb/mc≈3subscript𝑚𝑏subscript𝑚𝑐3m_{b}/m_{c}\approx 3, if one uses typical values for the constituent quark masses. lipkin85 . Very recently, b​b​q¯​q¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑞¯𝑞bb\bar{q}\bar{q} was shown to be stable against strong decays but not its charm counterpart c​c​q¯​q¯𝑐𝑐¯𝑞¯𝑞cc\bar{q}\bar{q}, nor the mixed (beauty+charm) b​c​q¯​q¯𝑏𝑐¯𝑞¯𝑞bc\bar{q}\bar{q} state Karliner:2017qjm ; Eichten:2017ffp . For a detailed discussion on the stability of such systems, we refer to the recent study in Ref. Czarnecki:2017vco .

IV Tetraquark-Meson Mass Inequalities

One can estimate the lower bounds of the ground state energy levels of the fully-heavy four-quark systems by using the variational approach, as suggested long ago by Nussinov Nussinov:1983vh and by Bertlmann and Martin Bertlmann:1979zs . This approach was tested by the lattice QCD calculations of Weingarten Weingarten:1983uj and also by the rigorous calculations in the vectorlike gauge theories (QCD) by Witten Witten:1983ut . We attempt to extend Nussinov’s approach to the fully-heavy four-quark bound states and obtain inequalities between the tetraquark states and the corresponding heavy quarkonia in the following.

Let us consider the general Hamiltonian of four heavy quarks with pair-wise interactions:

The inequalities for all possible fully-heavy tetraquarks are listed in Table 3. The corresponding numerical values are obtained using the spin-averaged quarkonium masses Mb​b¯​(1​S)=9.445​GeVsubscript𝑀𝑏¯𝑏1𝑆9.445GeVM_{b\bar{b}}(1S)=9.445~{}\text{GeV}, Mc​c¯​(1​S)=3.069​GeVsubscript𝑀𝑐¯𝑐1𝑆3.069GeVM_{c\bar{c}}(1S)=3.069~{}\text{GeV} and Mc​b¯​(1​S)=6.324​GeVsubscript𝑀𝑐¯𝑏1𝑆6.324GeVM_{c\bar{b}}(1S)=6.324~{}\text{GeV}. Since the Bc∗​(13​S1)superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑐superscript13subscript𝑆1B_{c}^{*}(1^{3}S_{1}) meson has not been observed, for Mc​b¯​(1​S)subscript𝑀𝑐¯𝑏1𝑆M_{c\bar{b}}(1S) we used the average value of the theoretical predictions of Godfrey–Isgur Model Godfrey:2004ya and the Cornell potential model from Ref. Eichten:1994gt .

If we compare the so-obtained approximate upper bound in the fully-bottom sector with the earlier theoretical predictions listed in Table 1, we find this value is indeed larger than all the model predictions except for that of Ref. Wang:2017jtz , which is calculated by means of QCD sum rules and has a large uncertainty.

V Possible Decays of Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}

The main difficulties in the experimental observation of fully-bottom tetraquark mesons are related to the production mechanisms and observation of the main decay modes. A very recent study discussed the production of the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state at the LHC, concluding that the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} is supposed to be very narrow and likely to be discovered Eichten:2017ual . Another recent study Vega-Morales:2017pmm also discussed the possible production of a narrow scalar resonance around 18∼19similar-to181918\sim 19 GeV at the LHC.777The decay of such resonance into four-lepton final state is also explored to disentangle whether it would be a tetraquark or something more exotic. In the following, we will discuss the decays of such a state and provide a rough estimate of its width. We will argue that the width is at least a few tens of MeV.

As shown in Table 1, most of the models predict the ground-state fully-bottom tetraquark to be below the ηb​ηbsubscript𝜂𝑏subscript𝜂𝑏\eta_{b}\eta_{b} threshold. Because of this, one expects its width to be almost saturated by the following decay modes: 1) decays into final states containing a pair of bottom and anti-bottom quarks; 2) decays into hadrons of lighter flavors. The former is dominated by one-gluon exchange, while the latter should be dominated by two gluons. Figure 2 shows an example of the decay into a pair of open-bottom mesons. Because the gluons are at the scale of mbsubscript𝑚𝑏m_{b}, one expects the first type of decays to dominate over the second. As it is not an easy task to calculate partial decay widths into given exclusive decay modes, in the following we provide a rough estimate of the inclusive decay width of the Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} ground-state based on the first decay mode.

The inclusive width of the Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} into final states with a pair of b𝑏b and b¯¯𝑏\bar{b} quarks can be described as a two-step process triggered by a transition operator 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} as

⟨h1​h2​…|𝒯|Xb​b​b¯​b¯⟩=⟨h1​h2​…|𝒯2|b1​b¯4​g⟩⋅⟨b1​b¯4​g|𝒯1|b1​b2​b¯3​b¯4⟩,quantum-operator-productsubscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…𝒯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏quantum-operator-productsubscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…subscript𝒯2subscript𝑏1subscript¯𝑏4𝑔missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression⋅absentquantum-operator-productsubscript𝑏1subscript¯𝑏4𝑔subscript𝒯1subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2subscript¯𝑏3subscript¯𝑏4\begin{array}[]{rcl}\langle h_{1}h_{2}\ldots|\mathcal{T}|X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}\rangle&=&\langle h_{1}h_{2}...|\mathcal{T}_{2}|b_{1}\bar{b}_{4}g\rangle\\ &&\cdot\langle b_{1}\bar{b}_{4}g|\mathcal{T}_{1}|b_{1}b_{2}\bar{b}_{3}\bar{b}_{4}\rangle\,,\end{array} (25)

where h1subscriptℎ1h_{1} and h2subscriptℎ2h_{2} indicate possible bottom hadrons allowed by the spin-parity quantum numbers and the available phase space. Here 𝒯1subscript𝒯1\mathcal{T}_{1} is operator for the coupling of a heavy quark-antiquark pair to a gluon, given by 4​π​αs​Q¯​12​λa​γμ​Q​ϵμa4𝜋subscript𝛼𝑠¯𝑄12subscript𝜆𝑎superscript𝛾𝜇𝑄subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝜇\sqrt{4\pi\alpha_{s}}~{}\bar{Q}\frac{1}{2}\lambda_{a}\gamma^{\mu}Q\epsilon^{a}_{\mu}, and 𝒯2subscript𝒯2\mathcal{T}_{2} is responsible for the transition from b​b¯​g𝑏¯𝑏𝑔b\bar{b}g to the final hadronic states. We need to sum up all the possible final states generated at the second vertex of Fig. 2, which includes not only two-body but also many-body final states. As a result, only the second factor (𝒯1subscript𝒯1\mathcal{T}_{1}) in the above equation matters.

The Q¯​Q¯𝑄𝑄\bar{Q}Q annihilation at short distances requires a direct dependence on the zero-point wave function of the color-octet Q¯​Q¯𝑄𝑄\bar{Q}Q inside the four-body bound state, RQ​Q¯(8)​(0)subscript𝑅𝑄subscript¯𝑄80R_{Q\bar{Q}_{(8)}}(0). Hence,

Γ​(Xb​b​b¯​b¯→h1​h2​…)∝αs​(mb)​|Rb​b¯(8)​(0)|2​ .proportional-toΓ→subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏subscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…subscript𝛼𝑠subscript𝑚𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑏subscript¯𝑏802 \Gamma(X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}\to h_{1}h_{2}\ldots)\propto\alpha_{s}(m_{b})~{}|R_{b\bar{b}_{(8)}}(0)|^{2}\mbox{ }. (26)

It is well-known that the ηbsubscript𝜂𝑏\eta_{b} decay width is saturated by two-gluon exchange, and the ηbsubscript𝜂𝑏\eta_{b} inclusive decay width is Γ​(ηb→hadrons)∝αs2​(mb)​|Rb​b¯(1)​(0)|2proportional-toΓ→subscript𝜂𝑏hadronssuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑠2subscript𝑚𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑏subscript¯𝑏102\Gamma(\eta_{b}\to\mbox{hadrons})\propto\alpha_{s}^{2}(m_{b})~{}|R_{b\bar{b}_{(1)}}(0)|^{2} voloshin:1978Rosner:1988 . The wave function at origin of a color-octet b​b¯(8)𝑏subscript¯𝑏8b\bar{b}_{(8)} pair might be larger than that of the asymptotic color-singlet b​b¯(1)𝑏subscript¯𝑏1b\bar{b}_{(1)}, namely a bottomonium Isgur:1984bm . However, at the present stage there is no need for a precise calculation of the width. For an order-of-magnitude estimate, one may simply assume |Rb​b¯(8)​(0)|2∼|Rb​b¯(1)​(0)|2similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑏subscript¯𝑏802superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑏subscript¯𝑏102|R_{b\bar{b}_{(8)}}(0)|^{2}\sim|R_{b\bar{b}_{(1)}}(0)|^{2}. Therefore, we can estimate the inclusive width of the Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} decays into hadrons containing b𝑏b and b¯¯𝑏\bar{b} as

Γ​(Xb​b​b¯​b¯→h1​h2​…)≃1αs​(mb)​Γ​(ηb→hadrons)​ .similar-to-or-equalsΓ→subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏subscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…1subscript𝛼𝑠subscript𝑚𝑏Γ→subscript𝜂𝑏hadrons \Gamma(X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}\to h_{1}h_{2}\ldots)\simeq\frac{1}{\alpha_{s}(m_{b})}\Gamma(\eta_{b}\to\mbox{hadrons})\mbox{ }. (27)

The ηbsubscript𝜂b\eta_{\rm b} dominantly decays into hadrons, hence, Γ​(ηb→hadrons)≈Γ​(ηb)=10−4+5Γ→subscript𝜂𝑏hadronsΓsubscript𝜂𝑏subscriptsuperscript1054\Gamma(\eta_{b}\to\mbox{hadrons})\approx\Gamma(\eta_{b})=10^{+5}_{-4} MeV Nakamura:2010zzi . Taking αs​(mb)=0.22subscript𝛼𝑠subscript𝑚𝑏0.22\alpha_{s}(m_{b})=0.22 Nakamura:2010zzi , and neglecting all other possible decay modes which should be subdominant, we get

Γ​(Xb​b​b¯​b¯)=𝒪​(50​MeV).Γsubscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏𝒪50MeV\Gamma(X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}})=\mathcal{O}(50~{}\textrm{MeV})\,. (28)

The previous width (of the order of a few tens of MeV) is large enough to make the resonance observable. Our estimate of Eq. (28) is of the same order of magnitude as an earlier prediction for similar systems chao:1981 , while it is much larger than the estimate of Ref. Karliner:2016zzc , 1.2 MeV. Similarly, we expect the width of the fully-charm tetraquark, if below the ηc​ηcsubscript𝜂𝑐subscript𝜂𝑐\eta_{c}\eta_{c} threshold, to be larger,

Γ​(Xc​c​c¯​c¯)≃Γ​(ηc)αs​(mc)=𝒪​(100​MeV).similar-to-or-equalsΓsubscript𝑋𝑐𝑐¯𝑐¯𝑐Γsubscript𝜂𝑐subscript𝛼𝑠subscript𝑚𝑐𝒪100MeV\Gamma(X_{cc\bar{c}\bar{c}})\simeq\frac{\Gamma(\eta_{c})}{\alpha_{s}(m_{c})}=\mathcal{O}(100~{}\textrm{MeV})\,. (29)

The fully-bottom tetraquark states could be searched for in final states including a pair of bottom hadrons, such as B​B¯𝐵¯𝐵B\bar{B}, Λb​Λ¯bsubscriptΛ𝑏subscript¯Λ𝑏\Lambda_{b}\bar{\Lambda}_{b}, Ξb​Ξ¯bsubscriptΞ𝑏subscript¯Ξ𝑏\Xi_{b}\bar{\Xi}_{b}, Σb​Σ¯bsubscriptΣ𝑏subscript¯Σ𝑏\Sigma_{b}\bar{\Sigma}_{b} and Ωb​Ω¯bsubscriptΩ𝑏subscript¯Ω𝑏\Omega_{b}\bar{\Omega}_{b}. They can also decay into a fully leptonic final state via an intermediate Υ​(1​S)​XΥ1𝑆𝑋\Upsilon(1S)X state as

Xb​b​b¯​b¯→Υ​(1​S)​X→l+​l−​l+​l−,→subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏Υ1𝑆𝑋→superscript𝑙superscript𝑙superscript𝑙superscript𝑙X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}}\to\Upsilon(1S)X\to l^{+}l^{-}l^{+}l^{-}, (30)

where l𝑙l can be τ𝜏\tau, μ𝜇\mu or e𝑒e, and X𝑋X could be the off-shell lowest vector bottomonium, X≡Υ​(1​S)∗𝑋Υsuperscript1𝑆X\equiv\Upsilon(1S)^{*}. This decay involves the annihilation of two b​b¯𝑏¯𝑏b\bar{b} pairs into virtual photons, so the branching fraction is expected to be small, 𝒪​(10−4∼10−8)𝒪similar-tosuperscript104superscript108\mathcal{O}(10^{-4}\sim 10^{-8}), as estimated in Karliner:2016zzc .888We have down-scaled the branching faction estimate by one order of magnitude in comparison with that in Ref. Karliner:2016zzc , since the total width estimated here is one order of magnitude larger. Despite of this, the multi-lepton final states are expected to provide a clean signal with a low background. The ideal place to look for the decays of Eq. (30) is the Large Hadron Collider experiments, where the Higgs boson cross section was measured by reconstructing a four-lepton final state cms:2015yvw . Because of this, a scan at relatively lower energies, of the order of 2​Mηb​(1​S)2subscript𝑀subscript𝜂𝑏1𝑆2M_{\eta_{b}(1S)}, should be almost straightforward at LHC.

VI Summary

We calculated the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy in terms of two different approximations for the tetraquark wave function. They were used to simplify the solution of the four-body problem.

In the first case, we provided an evaluation of the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy in an NREFT at the LO, where the potential is an OGE-induced color Coulomb potential. A nice feature of our approach is that the color wave function is completely given by |3¯12​334;11234⟩ketsubscript¯312subscript334subscript11234\left|\bar{\textbf{3}}_{12}\textbf{3}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle at the LO, and its mixing with |612​6¯34;11234⟩ketsubscript612subscript¯634subscript11234\left|\textbf{6}_{12}\bar{\textbf{6}}_{34};\textbf{1}_{1234}\right\rangle only occurs at higher orders. The solution of the four-body problem was simplified by making use of the symmetries introduced by Hylleraas and Ore in their study of polyelectrons, namely the bound states of two electrons and positrons. In our specific case, one of the above mentioned symmetries could be expressed as ψspatial​(b​b)=ψspatial​(b¯​b¯)subscript𝜓spatial𝑏𝑏subscript𝜓spatial¯𝑏¯𝑏\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(bb)=\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(\bar{b}\bar{b}), where ψspatial​(b​b)subscript𝜓spatial𝑏𝑏\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(bb) and ψspatial​(b¯​b¯)subscript𝜓spatial¯𝑏¯𝑏\psi_{\textrm{spatial}}(\bar{b}\bar{b}) are the spatial wave functions of the b​b𝑏𝑏bb and b¯​b¯¯𝑏¯𝑏\bar{b}\bar{b} systems, respectively. Thanks to this, the four-body problem was simplified by reducing the number of integration variables. In the second case, we calculated the b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} ground-state energy in a relativized diquark model. This model is characterized by OGE plus a confining potential. In the diquark model, the effective degree of freedom of the diquark, describing two strongly correlated quarks with no internal spatial excitations, is introduced. Tetraquark mesons are then obtained as two-body diquark-antidiquark bound states. Our results in both approaches—NREFT at LO (18.72±0.02plus-or-minus18.720.0218.72\pm 0.02 GeV) and relativized diquark model (18.75 GeV)—only differ by a few tens of MeV, and suggests the existence of a b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} bound-state below the ηb​ηbsubscript𝜂𝑏subscript𝜂𝑏\eta_{b}\eta_{b} threshold.

We also derived a set of approximate inequalities for the binding energies of the fully-heavy tetraquarks in terms of those of various heavy quarkonia. Instead of giving the values of the ground-state energies of the states of interest, the inequalities provide upper bounds on them. As expected, our LO NREFT and relativized diquark model results on the Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} ground-state mass satisfy the corresponding inequality.

Finally, we discussed the possible decay modes of the lowest fully-heavy tetraquarks and estimated the decay width of the ground state b​b​b¯​b¯𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏bb\bar{b}\bar{b} to be of 𝒪​(50​MeV)𝒪50MeV\mathcal{O}(50~{}\text{MeV}). We hope our results might provide useful references in the search for fully-heavy tetraquarks in ongoing LHC experiments. In particular, we suggest searching for the lowest Xb​b​b¯​b¯subscript𝑋𝑏𝑏¯𝑏¯𝑏X_{bb\bar{b}\bar{b}} in the relevant center-of-mass energy region around 18.7 GeV in the final states of four leptons or a pair of bottom hadrons such as B​B¯𝐵¯𝐵B\bar{B}, Λb​Λ¯bsubscriptΛ𝑏subscript¯Λ𝑏\Lambda_{b}\bar{\Lambda}_{b}, Ξb​Ξ¯bsubscriptΞ𝑏subscript¯Ξ𝑏\Xi_{b}\bar{\Xi}_{b}, Σb​Σ¯bsubscriptΣ𝑏subscript¯Σ𝑏\Sigma_{b}\bar{\Sigma}_{b} and Ωb​Ω¯bsubscriptΩ𝑏subscript¯Ω𝑏\Omega_{b}\bar{\Omega}_{b},

Note added

During the revision process of this manuscript, a preliminary CMS analysis (not yet approved by the collaboration) was presented in APS April meeting Durgut , hinting at a potential four-lepton excess in the mass range of 18∼19similar-to181918\sim 19 GeV.
